div.head: OPEN SESSION, May 11
div.p: Kimball called the meeting to order at 9:05 a.m. He warned that each speaker was responsible for informing the Chairman if any classified, privileged, or off-the-record information was being discussed. It was assumed that all other information was on the record. Kimball recognized David Goldman, a candidate to join the staff of the Historian’s Office, and Slany noted that vacancies were being filled.

Kimball stated that since no members of the press were present, Slany could proceed with a discussion of agenda changes. It was announced that Ken Walters would substitute for John Hancock in a briefing on the new executive order; Frank Machak might also speak; and the ISOO briefing scheduled for Friday had been canceled. The minutes of the February meeting were approved with one correction requested by Hogan—-“Ohio State University” instead of “Ohio University”—on page 7. Slany noted that the minutes would now be available to the public at the Department’s FOIA reading room.

div.head: Report by the Historian
div.p: Slany noted that the written report included in the briefing material summarized the status of the Foreign Relations series. Slany said that 1995 should be a banner year for publication, but unless clearance problems with other agencies were resolved, not much would be published next year. The Office Was within range of the 30-year line, but it was slipping away because of clearance difficulties with the CIA. Thanks to the Committee’s interest, officers of the Department have helped make available needed records of the Department. The Office was increasingly successful in gaining access to CIA records.

Discussion of access to the audiotapes of the telephone conversations of President Johnson should be deferred as an agenda item for several more months to see how the project was working. The plan for using the LBJ telephone conversations called for making a careful, thoughtful selection to ensure that the most significant parts were reflected in the series. This in turn should facilitate the eventual opening of the entire collection at the LBJ Library. At its last meeting, the Committee had recommended adding a statement to the prefaces of LBJ volumes explaining how the telephone conversations were used. Kimball noted that the preface for each volume should also note problems or successes in access to intelligence documents and other specialized material.

Slany described a new problem in preparing the series even as old obstacles were being rolled back: the discovery of new records was having a potential impact on the publication of volumes. Volumes close to publication were being delayed while added materials were edited, cleared, and typeset. It would be useful to have the Committee’s advice concerning the point at which the Office should go forward with the manuscript of any particular volume at hand. Compiling was no longer a tidy process because important new documents continuously appeared. The Committee might advise on whether the Office should hold off publishing in order to add material in cleared or almost-cleared volumes.

Van Camp raised the question of access to CIA records. Kimball indicated that this would be discussed. It was not clear how long it would take the new Director to
develop a new structure, but it was not likely to happen quickly. Herring said that access might be even slower in the short term. Van Camp suggested that the Office determine when a volume has passed the point beyond which it is too costly to make changes. The preface should note that in the “changing informational environment” new materials may come to light, and suggest that the reader check future volumes.

Kimball asked what would happen if new materials invalidated the original thrust of a volume. He felt that HO historians should make the decision, but a “quick reaction” group of at least two Committee members should be available to examine significant material and recommend either delay or publication.

Davis asked whether supplements to volumes had ever been considered. There was some general discussion of various types of supplements, add-ons, inserts, etc. Slany noted that the Office was reluctant to include material in supplements or inserts that might become separated in libraries. Kimball pointed out that only three documents were at issue in the 1961–1963 Japan compilation. Davis reminded the Committee that encyclopedias used to publish supplements. Rosenberg noted that the Army official histories included packets of maps. Picker wondered about inserting new pages in volumes and suggested that a group of supplements might eventually be needed. Kimball wondered whether a cumulative index would be feasible. Rosenberg warned that the existence of a supplement might encourage declassifies to delay their decisions. She suggested that the issue of supplements be reevaluated after a year.

Kimball noted that the Committee’s discussion had been mixing declassification and access issues. The former was the greater problem, with a declassification schedule set by law. Documents could be available well before Foreign Relations volumes were published. Rosenberg said that Congress must be notified if publication was likely to stop. Kimball said that this was a different issue. The chief concern under discussion here was that new document collections might change the thrust of published volumes.

Picker said that if the two mandated goals were in conflict, accuracy should prevail. Kimball noted that most newly discovered documents caused no fundamental changes and could be included in a supplemental volume. CD-ROM was an even more flexible format. New finds could be announced in State Department Dispatch or another publication. The British were doing something like this.

Slany then turned to the status of National Security Agency records. There has been no response to a query of last year concerning access to intercepts from naval vessels in the Tonkin Gulf incident. The Foreign Relations volume has long since been published, so any new documents would have to come out in a retrospective volume. Kimball said that there had been a little progress, but not appropriate progress. When he asked to see the BRUSA agreement on intelligence-sharing, he alone got to see only parts of it.

After Slany said the access agreement with NSA was not as complete as those with the CIA and NSC, Kimball called it “procedurally useless.” He believed that if the need could be demonstrated, access would be granted. Perhaps seeing contemporary paraphrases of NSA intercepts would avoid compromising cryptographic materials. Thus far, the only people that NSA had sent for consultation were those about to retire.

Nancy Smith pointed out that it was not hard to get additional briefings for special access if a specific person were designated for the purpose. Humphrey wondered whether raw intercepts mattered unless they affected policy. Since President Johnson received raw intercepts, these should be in the LBJ Library. Kimball said that the Committee needed to prove to agencies that “we’re not the bad guys.” Humphrey pointed out that intercepts could be vital for coverage of the USS Liberty and USS Pueblo incidents. Nancy Smith noted that some should be in the LBJ Library, but agency clearance would still be required.

Slany then turned to action items from the February meeting. The first of these was the Committee’s request for stationery. The Department was aware of this request. The matter was still under advisement, but the Committee would probably have stationery by the time of the next scheduled meeting.

Leffler then brought up a joint State–NARA letter seeking guidelines on declassification of National Security Council records. Nancy Smith said that the Presidential Libraries were seeking guidelines for clearance of NSC materials. NSC had not yet received the request, guidelines would take a long time to prepare, and the impact of the new executive order had to be considered. At present, the Presidential Libraries had the advisory records and NARA had the administrative records. The Clinton administration was declaring all NSC documents to be Presidential and exempt from FOIA. Herschler said that Presidential Library materials would be subject to mandatory review. Smith replied that agencies had not given the Libraries the authority to declassify top-level documents.

Kimball raised the issue of reviews of Foreign Relations volumes by outside scholars. Slany indicated that the Office had no way at the moment of finding funds for contracts for such reviews. The only available consultants for such reviews were currently active-duty senior Foreign Service officers.

div.head: Publication of Japan Chapter in Foreign Relations, 1961-1963, Volume XXII
div.p: Kimball then turned to the next agenda item, a discussion of the publication of the 1961–1963 Northeast Asia volume without the chapter on Japan. Officials at the highest levels of the executive branch had advised the postponement of the discussion of this issue for a period of time. The Committee was not happy about this delay. It is clear that this is an important issue that will create precedents for the entire issue of access and clearance. But the Committee is convinced that this is not a bad faith request. It is being actively discussed by officials at the highest levels of the Executive Branch. The Committee feels that it is the right thing to do to give those officials a little more time. So the Committee will come back for a special meeting early in June to assess the response it expects to get by that time.

Schaller asked what the Committee would do if it received a negative response that seriously omitted documents the Committee felt were important. Kimball said that the Committee had made clear what the necessary parameters were in terms of documents to be included. If a response came back that was a partial or full negative, the Committee would be able to discuss this at its special meeting in June.

div.head: Planning for Publication of the Record of the Nixon and Ford Administrations
div.p: The Committee reconvened at 10:45 a.m. and took up the issue of planning for the Foreign Relations volumes that will cover the Nixon and Ford administrations. Kimball asked Slany to address the issue.

Slany responded that the Historian’s Office has been working with Nancy Smith of the Office of the Presidential Libraries of the National Archives and would schedule a meeting in May with Stan Mortenson, the lawyer representing the Nixon estate, concerning the critical issue of access to the Nixon documentation. He noted that he had not yet talked to John Taylor, Director of the Nixon Library, about access. He pointed out that the Presidential Records Act of 1977 did, of course, give the Archivist the responsibility for granting access to the Nixon records.

Slany stated that what must be done first is define the scope of the volumes. The structure and emphasis of the proposed volumes had been discussed within HO, and draft outlines of 25 volumes had been developed for each of the periods covering the first 4 years of the Nixon administration and the subsequent Nixon/Ford administration. Slany stated that he felt the scope of the coverage proposed was what HO resources could accommodate. It was slightly less than for the Johnson years, which will have 35 volumes covering 5 years.

Slany asked the Committee for suggestions. He noted that the volume outlines in the briefing package came out of discussions in the Office among the senior FSOs assigned to HO and was based on their professional sense of the importance of events. He asked whether the lists of proposed volumes struck a proper balance in terms of geographic and topical emphasis.

Kimball noted that the Committee has been reluctant to offer the type of specific advice HO was seeking. Experts on the foreign policy of the Nixon administration were available and might be hired to comment on the planning process for the volumes envisioned. Slany stated that HO was seeking only a general sense of guidance from the Committee.

Rosenberg commented on the outline of volumes proposed for the first 4 years of the Nixon administration: one volume for Latin America and one volume for Africa seemed inadequate. She also pointed out that she saw a need for a compilation on information policy; Herring agreed with Rosenberg that one volume for Latin America was inadequate.

Kimball said that he was glad to see a proposed volume on the global economy. In his view, transnational issues will demand increasing consideration in the Foreign Relations series. He thought that the oil crisis of the 1970s might bring this requirement to the fore.

Herring pointed to the significance of a remark made by David Patterson that the list of volumes was necessarily prepared without consulting the documentation upon which they would be based. Rosenberg observed that any proposed framework of volumes would evolve as the compilers proceed with their research.

Slany stated that National Archives requirements relating to preparing and processing the records require preliminary planning for the volumes, even if the emphasis later changes. Nancy Smith supported Slany’s observation concerning the need for preliminary planning, particularly with respect to the Nixon documentation, which is involved in legal complications that might require NARA to review the documents for restrictions other than national security restrictions before HO historians see them.

Hogan observed that Foreign Relations volumes tend to define the field of diplomatic research. Graduate students typically begin their research by consulting Foreign Relations volumes. With that in mind, he wondered whether it might not be important to circulate the proposed schedule of volumes to recognized experts in the field. Kimball said that Hogan’s suggestion was sound, but more appropriate after HO research had refined the list.

Davis commented that in dealing with the Nixon administration, it will be necessary to take Kissinger into account, and he advised compilers to read Kissinger’s writings. Pointing out that the State Department became less and less a central player in the formulation of foreign policy, he suggested that compilers will have to range further afield into the records of other agencies. Foreign policy material might have to be researched at state and local levels.

Kimball noted that legislation governing the preparation of the Foreign Relations series limited the foreign policy concerns documented in the volumes to the federal level. He also observed that research into the records of other agencies and in private collections had enriched the volumes in recent years.

Van Camp turned the Committee’s attention to the problems relating to gaining access to the Nixon and Kissinger materials. Kimball pointed to the report to the Committee which indicated that HO is in the process of negotiating for access to these materials. Herring asked whether Kissinger’s records as National Security Adviser are at NARA or the Library of Congress. William Cunliffe, Director of the Nixon Presidential Historical Materials Project, stated that the Kissinger materials are at the Library of Congress and NARA is in the process of providing finding aids on the Nixon materials, which he thought included material concerning Kissinger’s role as National Security Adviser.

Slany noted that to some extent this is a resource issue. The Department is now providing $80,00-90,000/year in subsidies to the LBJ Library to facilitate priority State access without hindering non-governmental researchers, and may have to provide even more to NARA to subsidize work on the Nixon records.

Nancy Smith said that no partial processing has been done on the Nixon records. Such processing must be completed before HO compilers can begin their research in the records. Kimball asked when NARA would be able to do this. Cunliffe responded that the requirements of Foreign Relations research will provide the impetus to the processing. Nancy Smith added that resources from the State Department will be necessary to deal with the problem. The Nixon Project includes thousands of boxes in the national security files, and processing the many hours of tapes will be an immense job.

Herring noted that processing at the LBJ Library had begun in the 1970s, and he expressed concern about the later start with! the Nixon documentation. Nancy Smith noted that under the statute, NARA was supposed to give priority in processing to Watergate material, but that they were getting to the end of that project. Humphrey observed that the National Security File at the LBJ Library is about one third the size of that in the Nixon Project.

Kimball expressed concern about the impact of these problems on the Foreign Relations series. He felt there was a pressing need for more detailed planning, and he asked how HO and NARA planned to attack the problems of access and processing.

Herring seconded Kimball’s concerns. Kimball asked Smith if NARA had a plan to meet these concerns. Smith stated that helpful contacts with HO had begun to define Foreign Relations needs in terms of files, tapes, and other materials to be researched. Kimball asked if HO historians could consult finding aids to the Nixon records. Smith responded with a qualified yes, although some of the finding aids, such as the one relating to the audiotapes, are issues under litigation. HO needs to work out the access problem with Mortenson.

Kimball indicated that he was uneasy without a well-defined action plan. Leffler asked if HO had written to Nixon’s lawyers Slany responded that he had, but no meeting had been arranged. He pointed out that overall access to the Nixon records will be defined by the Archivist of the United States. The Nixon estate retains the right, however, to preview any material made available to researchers, in order to meet the concerns of the estate with respect to privacy matters. HO’s concern is to reach agreement with the lawyers representing the estate that Foreign Relations is a valid official project, thus facilitating research without the necessity of prior review of materials.

Smith observed that precedent had been established by other official historians doing research in the Nixon documentation on this basis. She added that nothing on the scale proposed by HO had been undertaken.

Kimball again expressed concern about the lack of a detailed action plan for research scheduled to begin as early as next year. He said that the Committee could not play a part in addressing the complex problems involved in gaining access without such a plan.

Slany said that he is asking the Committee whether the HO plan for the Nixon volumes will provide adequate coverage. Leffler commented that he did not think the proposed list of volumes would affect the access issue. No matter how many volumes there were, HO would need to see all relevant foreign policy materials.

Kimball asked when the letter concerning access had been sent to Mortenson. Slany responded that it had been sent last month, and he had talked to Mortenson this month. Mortenson is currently involved in litigation, and negotiations with HO are necessarily affected by his other commitments.

Nancy Smith said that NARA is more than willing to assist in preparing the kind of plan Kimball was asking for. She noted, however, that because of pending litigation
relating to the Nixon materials, it is difficult for NARA to take written positions on problems such as HO access to the materials.

div.head: New Executive Order on National Security Information
div.p: Kimball turned the discussion at this point to the recently released Executive Order 12958 on national security information.

Ken Walters of the Bureau of Diplomatic Security briefed the Committee on the implementation of the order and the implications for the Department of State. He reviewed the salient aspects of the order and noted that the State Department will respond to the order, in part, by stipulating that classification be kept to the lowest possible level. Guidelines concerning this had yet to be developed. Walters stated that a new panel will be established for classification appeals. National interests will be weighed against public interest with the assumption that as much as possible should be released. Walters noted that the State Department has until mid-October to meet certain requirements stipulated in the executive order. He expected the Department to be in full compliance with the order by the beginning of next year.
Kimball commented that the executive order did not include everything the Committee thought was important but it did reflect some of the Committee’s concerns.

Rosenberg asked about documents that had been previously reviewed and denied declassification. Would these documents be reconsidered for release under the new executive order? Will everything be opened up that is older than 25 years?

Walters referred these questions to Frank Machak. Machak observed that there were reasons that documents were initially denied declassification, and they will not automatically be declassified as a result of the new executive order. Machak asked for Committee input in fashioning a plan for implementation of the executive order. He noted that the State Department had gone from reviewing 1 million pages of documentation a year to 4-1/2 million pages. The Department hoped to increase that pace to 9 million pages a year to meet the requirements laid down in the new executive order. This posed a daunting challenge.

Machak said that a new environment exists partly because of the costs involved in generating and maintaining classified documentation, giving an obvious impetus to the orderly process of declassification. He noted that there is an interagency working group addressing the issue of automatic declassification. Machak hoped to have the Committee’s concerns in hand, even in the form of a preliminary checklist, when the interagency working group begins to meet next week.

Kimball asked what avenues the Committee could pursue to make certain its concerns were factored into planning for the implementation of the executive order. He stated that the Committee had definite positions, which had been previously enunciated, that should be taken into consideration. He asked who was in charge of the planning. Walters replied that Assistant Secretary for Diplomatic Security Quainton was in charge.

Leffler asked for Machak’s perspective on implementing the executive order. Machak briefly outlined the parameters of what he felt was possible concerning
declassification. A major concern of his was that the Department might get bogged down in working on materials of marginal importance to the foreign policy record. Machak would welcome the Committee’s suggestions for priorities for the declassification process.
The Committee adjourned for lunch at noon.

div.head: CLOSED SESSION, May 11
div.p: Kimball opened the afternoon session by stating that the agenda needed to be revised to include a report on the new executive order and the report of the Committee on the opening of Department of State files after 30 years instead of discussion of the Nixon tapes. Picker reported that the subcommittee on the Legal Adviser’s records was not yet ready to present its report, but would do so the following morning. Kimball turned to the subcommittee on the opening of the Department of State records after 30 years for its report.

div.head: Report of the Subcommittee on Opening the Department of State’s 30-Year Old Records
div.p: Rosenberg reported that the four-member subcommittee visited Archives II. The subcommittee had a tour, sampled withheld documents, and met with Tony Dalsimer. The members were impressed with the number of files that had been reviewed and with the streamlined review process now being used, since it is faster and more rational than the process used earlier. The subcommittee received a report of the progress made and the members were amazed at the large numbers of documents that had been declassified.

The subcommittee decided to look at some of the withheld documents. Using a list of the open lot files for 1961 to 1963, the members selected some file titles that they determined would have high research interest. They found that one lot file had a 40 percent withholding rate. They then looked at the files and the withheld documents themselves to attempt to determine any problems.

Rosenberg then listed the subcommittee’s suggestions and recommendations on the entire matter. She noted that, according to Dalsimer, the guidelines promised from the Department of Defense were almost completed, and the subcommittee’s first recommendation was to get those guidelines. The second recommendation was to pursue the CIA equity issue. The Committee has repeatedly asked CIA to send someone in authority to the Archives to review documents with CIA equity. According to the minutes of the last Committee meeting, Frank Machak said that he would pursue that matter, and he has done so.

Machak then commented on a meeting scheduled for the last Wednesday of the month, May 31, with CIA officials, at which those issues raised by the subcommittee would be reviewed. All the appropriate counterparts would be at the meeting and were anxious to review the problem. Rosenberg reiterated that the Committee wanted a CIA official with authority to declassify to become involved in the process. Kimball noted that he spoke with John Pereira at CIA, who said that solution makes sense. He also spoke with Jack Wright on the phone about 3 to 6 months ago. Wright also said he would give the Committee a decision, but so far nothing has been done.

Machak repeated that all the appropriate people would be at the meeting, including Pereira. He (Machak) and his staff would attend and do what they could to improve the situation. He also noted that problems will arise from any approach, and whether the rule applies to 25 or 30 years makes no difference.

Dalsimer mentioned and read from a section of a letter from Leo Hazlewood, Executive Director of CIA, to Kimball in which Hazlewood commented that there are no guidelines for CIA equity. Dalsimer suggested that CIA was not willing to provide guidelines.

Schaller pointed out that when reviewing the withheld documents at Archives II, a particular problem was revealed. Often, numerous documents were packaged together, and even though the CIA content within the group of documents was small, the entire file was withheld because all the documents were bound together and considered as a unit.

Leffler added that often the solution to that problem would be as simple as unfastening a staple or removing documents from a binder. Some of the packages they saw had many Department of State memoranda that were still classified because of the practice of keeping all documents together.

Rosenberg said the subcommittee’s third recommendation was that these files be re-reviewed, since the binders or packages can be broken down and the documents separated. The subcommittee wanted the files to be reviewed again after the DOD guidelines are received.

With regard to the documents in binders, Dalsimer mentioned that a few weeks ago there was some discussion of not treating the package as one document. Marvin Russell interjected, however, that some pages in a binder, like those from the NSC, are kept together. Dalsimer went on to say that State reviewers at NARA are already taking these packets apart and, if researchers request a review, they will re-review the documents after the DOD guidelines are received.

Rosenberg went on to the subcommittee’s fourth recommendation: a good list of the open files has been prepared; that and future lists should be given to the Committee regularly, perhaps on a quarterly basis. The list would be distributed to the constituent organizations.
Leffler said he had a copy of the list and would pass it around so the other Committee members could see it.

Davis asked if the lists are classified, and Rosenberg replied that the lists are open and fully accessible to everyone. They can and should be put on the Federal Bulletin Board, Internet, and distributed in other forms to reach a wide audience.

Kimball asked Rosenberg to give some thought to the ways this information could be disseminated and to develop a procedure to do so. Van Camp indicated that she thought NARA already has a procedure to disseminate the information, and Rosenberg mentioned that one of the primary ways the information was publicized was in the SHAFR Newsletter.

Kimball suggested that NARA handle the distribution, rather than make the Committee responsible for dissemination of the information. Michael Kurtz of NARA suggested that it could go out on the Internet. Kimball was receptive to the suggestion, indicating that the Committee could discuss the matter. Hogan expressed his view that the SHAFR Newsletter was probably the best resource for publicizing the information.

Leffler turned again to a discussion of the files. He looked at an S/P lot file of 46 boxes, of which 16 were still withheld. He said that the portion still classified was usually given by a percentage of the whole, but to say that 3 percent or so was still classified was very misleading because it masked the fact that it is usually the most significant documents that remain classified. Many of the documents in this lot file, which covered the years 1948-1963, are from the late 1940s and early 1950s, and some of them continue to remain classified.

Kimball noted the problem is one of differences in the standards used. As the standards for declassification change, the older documents are usually not re-reviewed. Leffler pointed out, however, that the documents he spoke of were re-reviewed in December 1994, but even so 16 of 46 boxes were still classified. Rosenberg noted that those documents from the 1940s and 1950s were in the files primarily from 1961-1963.

Kimball asked about the subcommittee’s sense of the standards of review. Leffler admitted that it was difficult to draw any conclusion. He used as an example a group of documents bound together in a thick file. One of the documents had a paper clip at a quote taken from a CIA document. That the documents were bound together and that one had a CIA reference seemed to determine that the whole file would not be declassified. Overall, Leffler indicated he was disappointed by the results of the declassification process as evidenced by the fact that 16 of 46 PPS boxes remained closed after review.

Kimball noted that Dalsimer was nodding his head in agreement to that comment, indicating that the problem was the packaging of documents. Leffler concluded that little could be said about standards of declassification at this point.

Rosenberg noted that there were some documents that had been withheld because of Department of State exception, but it was rare. She concluded the report of the subcommittee. The other members had no additional comments to make.

Kimball asked Dalsimer if the minutes of the meeting would be sufficient to request that documents be unpackaged or unbound and then be re-reviewed. Dalsimer said that the minutes would be accepted as the Committee’s request. To be certain the record was unambiguous, Kimball stated that the Committee requests a re-review of the individual documents contained in packages that are broken apart.

div.head: NARA Comments on the Executive Order on National Security Information and Access to Records at the Presidential Libraries
div.p: Kimball introduced Nancy Smith and Michael Kurtz from NARA for comment on the new executive order and access to records at the Presidential Libraries.

Kurtz began by addressing the provisions of the new executive order that required review of 466 million documents over the next 5 years. Based on past experience with bulk declassification orders, the agencies will need help to get through the documents. During the 5-year period of review, the agencies would look to NARA for guidance and assistance. The goal is to review 15 percent of the documents each year for 5 years.

Kurtz informed the Committee that on June 8 NARA will host an interagency meeting on how to handle declassification under the provisions contained in the new executive order. NARA would encourage an interagency team approach. There will also be an open forum at the SHAFR meeting in Annapolis on declassification. NARA is also in contact with the Society for Military Historians and will be in touch with any other group that can offer insight and recommendations on implementation of the order.

NARA is also going to prepare a declassification database. The plans now call for setting up a system called GILS—Government Information Locator System. The government is currently working on this, and NARA will tie its database into the GILS database. NARA and other agencies are training on GILS.

Kurtz noted that NARA has a good working relationship with the Department of State and other agencies as well as with the military. All sides are concerned about implementing the new executive order and want to work together on it. He mentioned : that there was a CIA-sponsored conference on declassification and the executive order last week, which he attended.

After some brief comments in which Kimball indicated he was gratified to see that the 15-percent-per-year policy was retained in the executive order, Rosenberg expressed concern about the Committee members’ constituencies. In her view scholars will assume that documents are now on the new executive order standards when they are not, and she asked if there had been any discussion about reviewing older documents.
Kurtz stated that all documents 25 years old or older must be re-reviewed, according to the new executive order. Nancy Smith concurred, saying that the executive order must cover all old material.

Regarding that situation, Machak expressed some concern about the other side of the problem: where to stop in the re-review process. He merely raised the question at this point, but could not offer any recommendations or conclusions yet. He thought there might be a period of time for a mandatory review, perhaps 2 years. He commented that the Committee could raise this question in order to focus attention on it and that procedures could be tailored to meet the specific problem.

Smith noted that there was a question regarding how those documents slated for mandatory review were to be handled. Documents not in an exempted category must be open after 25 years; all others must be reviewed. She explained that at present material in Presidential Libraries being held for classification reasons is reviewed first and then opened. The Office of Presidential Libraries is working closely with the Office of the National Archives on the process. A lot of material could be in one of nine exempted categories and both offices are trying to remove some of the exempted categories, such as the World War II category or JFK assassination documents. They are also looking at
country files where the status of a country has changed, such as Vietnam. These matters need to be worked out with the Office of the National Archives, but money is a problem. In any event, documents withheld because of classification will be reviewed first.

Smith continued by pointing out that a framework has to be developed for older documents, and agencies will be notified that they have to review them. She suggested a two-pronged approach: 1) on-site reviews, and 2) interagency review teams formed to conduct the reviews. The Presidential Libraries have been contacted, and some, such as the Reagan Library, have already replied in support of the approach. Smith also mentioned that the libraries want more comprehensive guidelines, but in general those guidelines usually apply to lower-level documents. She pointed out that the NSC conducted on-site reviews at the Eisenhower Library with good results.

Kimball mentioned that he recently spoke with the Director of the Eisenhower Library, who said that he had about 2,700 files that cannot be declassified. Smith said she thought the Library had about 5,000 or 6,000 pages that were not declassified.

Kimball returned to the question of World War II documents and noted that they posed a problem because of other agency or foreign government equity. He asked whether agencies could be told to come and review the documents by a certain date or they would be opened.

Machak said the government did not work that way. Kimball responded that apparently the Archives does. He asked Smith if the new Archivist of the United States would support on-site review. Smith answered that the issue will certainly be addressed by the new Archivist. He is willing to give agencies sufficient review time, and the Presidential Libraries will have to comply with the newly-mandated guidelines for opening records. Kurtz stressed that the approach would be one of cooperation rather than confrontation.

Smith stated that the new executive order does not address certain material, such as RD and formerly RD material, and guidelines will be required for that material. Smith suggested that guidelines from CIA and NSC would be helpful. Switching to the Johnson Library audiotapes question, Smith responded to Kimball’s questions that HO is funding two positions at the LBJ Library to work on the tapes. Ultimately, the tapes will be available to the public.

David Humphrey noted that the LBJ Library is not pursuing HO interests in the tapes to the exclusion of others. It works on specific time periods suggested by HO, but the Library then reviews all the tapes in that time span.

Smith then moved to the Nixon Library. She pointed out that the idea of the Nixon lawyers and agents presenting a major hurdle is probably an exaggeration. On small official requests for access, the Office of Presidential Libraries has made progress with these agents. The lawyers would probably want to review material after it was selected. Problems would arise on a document-by-document basis rather than on the larger question of access. Smith also reiterated the notion that foreign policy was Nixon’s main interest and therefore also his lawyers’, and they would want the material to be used.

Van Camp asked Kurtz about the government-wide database on declassified documents provided for in the E.O. and if such documents were being described, or is the goal only to provide government-wide tracking of the declassification status of documents.

Kurtz answered that it was hard at this point to say exactly what the ultimate purpose and shape of the database would be. The GILS system would indicate the nature of the different systems in place among the various agencies. Whether the system will grow into a broader, more responsive on-line one will depend on priorities and especially resources.

Machak stated that the Department of State database is document-oriented, which is not necessarily what scholars need. A document-by-document index for millions of pages may not be the best use of money.

Kimball advised the Committee to give Nancy Smith an indication of their support for on-site review procedures. George Chalou stated that the Department of Energy conducted on-site review and it worked well, proving that it could be done. Smith observed that the Iran-Contra declassification project at the Department of Justice involved an interagency review team with each agency representative having the power to declassify.

Machak reminded the Committee of the Federal budgetary problems and the travel and other costs of on-site review. He also stated that drop-dead dates to agencies just did not work. Smith disagreed, stating that on-site review can be very cost-effective for highly selective and focused files. Kurtz again stressed that the new executive order needed interagency cooperation to succeed. Smith said that her fear was that agencies would wait until the end of the 5-year period and then try for total exemptions of whole files.
Leffler stated that that NARA should send quarterly statements on what has been declassified to the SHAFR Newsletter. Kurtz agreed and said they can be disseminated on Internet as well.

div.head: Planning for Foreign Relations Volumes Documenting the Nixon and Ford Administrations
div.p: The discussion then shifted to planning for the Nixon/Ford volumes. Herring wondered if it would be useful for the Committee to approach the Nixon lawyers. Slany answered that officially NARA was responsible for providing access. Nixon agents were allowed a privacy review. He did not want Nixon’s lawyers insisting on pre-review of documents before HO saw them. Kimball suggested that the Committee was at Slany’s disposal.

Slany questioned whether HO should be approaching Nixon’s lawyer Stan Mortenson before making a request to NARA. Davis suggested that he approach the Nixon lawyers, and if that did not work, then the Committee could focus on the problem. Van Camp suggested a two-pronged approach.

Schaller commented that the ideal solution would be that HO be given carte blanche from the Nixon lawyers, to which Slany agreed. Kimball added that under any circumstances, Nixon’s agents had the right to review for privacy considerations. Rosenberg suggested that HO use finding aids to establish priorities before getting in touch with Nixon’s agents.

Hogan noted that a two-pronged approach by HO and the Committee constituted a plan. Kimball suggested that to justify money for the Nixon Library, the Department needed a plan for research, or at least a strategy, which laid out what assistance from the Committee was needed.
Schaller asked if the Library had finding aids and, if so, who produced them. David Langbart explained that they were done at the time of Nixon’s resignation and prepared in great haste.

Rosenberg raised the issue of vacancies on the HO staff and asked how the Committee could help. Slany suggested that the Committee should reiterate what it had said before. The question of how and what kind of assistance should be given to NARA was another issue.

Picker suggested that Slany, Mortenson, and a representative from NARA’s Presidential Libraries Office should meet when the lawyer was available. The idea of sending a letter from the Committee could be shelved at least until then. Slany promised to report on his meeting with the Nixon lawyer and agreed that a letter was not needed yet.

Kimball again expressed his concern about the lack of an action plan that took into account both resources and an assessment of the amount and nature of the files to be examined at the Nixon Library. Rosenberg asked if the first Nixon administration’s records, which were approaching 25 years old, were under the provisions of the new executive order. Chalou suggested that they would probably be considered special category material and the order would not apply to them.
At this point the meeting adjourned briefly and reconvened at 3:40 p.m.

Kimball indicated that he would request information from Nancy Smith and NARA regarding a Mandatory Declassification Group, which, he believes, is a training and study group that deals with standards issues. He wants to be sure that the declassification authority delegated to the NARA by the NSC is being used in the spirit intended.

Humphrey noted that the NSC has indicated that, under the new executive order, it no longer needs to see White House documents for declassification. The LBJ Library has already stopped submitting them to NSC.

div.head: Declassification Problems of Foreign Relations Volumes
div.p:
Herring stated that the subcommittee report would be short. The Japan issue had already been dealt with. Kimball indicated that the Committee was still looking for a compromise on British Guiana, but it is premature to expect a final resolution until we see the response on the Japan volume. Herring noted that the CIA’s letter on British Guiana left open the possibility of a compromise. Herring also noted that the CIA had established
a review board for covert actions, a panel that would decide when to acknowledge them. CIA recognition of covert actions in British Guiana would resolve the issue.

Picker commented that the CIA people with whom they met stated that if CIA acknowledged the covert operation, they would be ready to agree to open all the related documents. Slany indicated that the documents had been referred to the NSC with the request that it overrule CIA. Herschler noted that all the documents in question were State or White House documents with CIA equity. CIA wanted to excise mention of itself and of covert operations. Picker commented that the Agency had changed its position from a “no” on Woolsey’s last day to a position in an April letter that opened the possibility of a retreat. The Committee has been informed that the CIA committee will meet within a week to decide.

Davis indicated that the subcommittee on CIA records did not get into the Guatemala issue. Slany noted that HO had collected, with the help of CIA, over 1,000 pages of CIA documents on Guatemala for a supplementary volume. HO will be examining them, looking for other sources, and will seek to clear and add the Guatemala documents originally excised from the 1952-1954 Foreign Relations volume published in 1984. Kimball stated that HO had gotten involved in an area of interest to the CIA History Staff. HO should discuss with CIA what the respective objectives were so that the two projects didn’t significantly overlap.

Rosenberg asked what else would be included in the catch-up intelligence volume. Slany stated that HO had not yet completed its planning. Iran remains to be done, but Guatemala has a higher priority. Rosenberg commented that the volume needed more detailed planning. In particular she wanted to know if it would be limited to the 11 covert actions admitted by Woolsey.

Slany stated that staff limits had prevented making great progress. What had been done so far had been the work of senior Foreign Service officers on short-tour assignment to HO. In terms of priorities, HO would have to give greatest attention to Kennedy and Johnson administration volumes. Kimball asked whether some limited amount of staff time could be put into planning at this stage? Slany replied that the Guatemala documentation was extensive enough to argue for a separate volume. Kimball indicated that the Committee would be ready to evaluate a recommendation for a single volume on Guatemala. Slany responded that HO would have a recommendation ready for the next meeting. Rosenberg reiterated her concern about planning for the other intelligence issues on Woolsey’s list.
The Committee adjourned for a bresik and reconvened at 4:05 p.m.

div.head: Report of the Subcommittee on CIA Records
div.p: The subcommittee on CIA records reported on a discussion with CIA officials on access to Agency records. Picker noted that John Pereira of CIA questioned what covert operations had to do with foreign affairs and asked why HO historians needed to know about contingency thinking that was not carried out. On the latter score, the subcommittee members pointed out to Pereira that the Foreign Relations legislation required that the volumes deal with policy alternatives.

Picker commented that the CIA people showed a surprising lack of understanding of what the Foreign Relations series was all about, were trying to second-guess HO on the historical significance of documents, and were unaware of the Foreign Relations legislation, which she found disturbing. Davis, Herring, and Hogan agreed with Picker’s observations.

Kimball asked Slany to put together a concise, straightforward description of the Foreign Relations series for CIA. Hogan indicated that he felt we were just around the corner from learning about all kinds of covert activities. Kimball noted that HO was asking for a serious change in precedent in what CIA reveals.

Kimball then asked the Committee to focus on Friday morning’s meeting with CIA people. What issues should be raised? What do we do about the immediate pressing problem of delays in CIA declassification decisions and their impact on the Foreign Relations publication schedule?

Picker asked whether the Committee should write a letter to new DCI John Deutch welcoming him. Davis commented that a letter to Deutch was premature at this stage. Van Camp asked whether the Committee could press CIA on meeting the deadlines provided in the legislation. Slany commented that, if CIA did not respond, this approach would result in publishing the volumes without the CIA material. Van Camp emphasized that the CIA declassification delays were the #1 priority, and the Committee needs to keep pressing the Agency. Kimball stated that the covert action issue was coming to a head. He felt that CIA’s Historical Research Policy Board is going to make a recommendation soon. Any action other than watchful waiting is premature.

Kimball asked for other questions or issues to raise on Friday with the CIA people. Van Camp suggested asking about how the new executive order would be implemented. Rosenberg proposed raising the issue of CIA’s providing on-site review people with declassification authority. Picker thought the Committee should emphasize again the importance of not duplicating Foreign Relations publications. Herring suggested asking for more information about the Historical Records Policy Board. Will it deal with general principles or specific cases?

Leffler raised again the issue of writing Deutch. What’s the harm in doing it now? Davis commented that a letter would deny Deutch the opportunity of acting as the Committee would wish without being in a position of reacting to it. Moreover, he wouldn’t read a letter sent in the next month anyway. Hogan stated that something should be done. Picker proposed writing a letter after The Washington Post has its next article on changes in CIA under Deutch. Hogan commented that the delays in the publication schedule do not allow for a month’s delay. Kimball suggested that the Committee put CIA on report for not meeting the legislatively mandated deadline.

After further discussion Kimball proposed asking Bennett Freeman how the Committee should communicate its distress; to CIA. The Committee should express to Freeman its fear that the whole series will be tied up by CIA delays—not just by the Japan issue but by the larger issue of covert action. Kimball then read Secretary Donilon’s letter
to Anthony Lake. A lengthy discussion ensued. Slany stated that an oral message to Freeman would be the wisest course.

div.head: CLOSED SESSION, May 12
div.p: The Committee reconvened at 9:15 a.m. Kimball checked to see whether everyone in attendance was either a State or CIA employee, and then issued the standard warning that the speaker would have the responsibility for identifying the type of information given: open, off-the-record, or classified.

Kimball asked Slany to distribute copies to the Committee of the newsletter issued by the historical program in the British Foreign and Commonwealth Office. He also asked the Historian’s Office to assemble a booklet including copies of the Foreign Relations statute and the Advisory Committee Charter. The booklet would be a “permanent” record that the Committee members could use.

div.head: Access to and Declassification of CIA Records: Report and Comments by CIA Officials
div.p: Kimball introduced Brian Latell, Director of the CIA’s Center for the Study of Intelligence, and Kay Oliver, Chief of the CSI History Staff. He asked the four CIA historians to identify themselves: Gerry Haines, Donald Steury, Scott Koch, and Michael Warner (one CIA historian, Kevin Ruffner, was not present). Kimball then asked the Committee members to identify themselves for the benefit of the CIA visitors.
[Begin Classified Discussion]
